Description: Hematite cylinder seal; a kilted priest with cup and pail, a bearded god in a flounced robe, with hands clasped, and a robed king with one hand raised and with an animal (gazelle?) offering, face the god with extended arm who wears an open skirt and who stands in an ascending posture; behind him stands a suppliant goddess. In the field are a human head (with forehead ornament), a pot, a ball-and-staff. There is a line border round the bottom of the seal. The simplified style is due to careful re-cutting, during which details of dress, such as flounces were erased; inscribed.
Curator's comments: According to catalogue the head-dress of the minor god may be evidence for the seal having originated in a Sippar workshop and this would be compatable with it's high quality of execution.
Bibliographic references: Collon 1986a / Catalogue of the Western Asiatic Seals in the British Museum: Cylinder Seals III: Isin-Larsa and Old Babylonian Periods (529)
Leichty E et al 1988a / Catalogue of the Babylonian Tablets in the British Museum, volume VIII: Tablets from Sippar 3 (p.300)
Acquisition name: From: Sir Ernest A T Wallis Budge
